author: paulhauner
content:
I've been doing thinking about how optimistic nodes should present information about optimistic blocks on the HTTP API.

There seem to be two broad paths we can take, and it's not immediately clear which is better. I've produced a short write-up on the two paths here:

https://hackmd.io/iLMSTklNQIGoSnOUoAbdcg

I'm interested to get some feedback from API consumers, please. Especially <@!144468805697929216> üôè

author: jgm
content: I tend to agree that both options have merit.  As such, would it perhaps make more sense to provide the data as we do today, but add an `optimistic` metadata flag at the top level of all relevant responses?  This would allow things like block explorers to follow the optimistic chain, and VCs to choose what to do with the data they receive based on the flag.

author: jgm
content: (An alternative would be to add a query parameter `allow_optimistic` which if set would return optimistic data and if not return a 503 in the case of the data being optimistic.  But I think the previous suggestion would be better, as it returns the useful information about if the data is optimistic or not.)

author: jgm
content: Also considering the SSE events: an `optimistic` flag makes sense in the event body for relevant events (`head`/`finalized_checkpoint`/`chain_reorg`, I think).  Not sure if we need a new event outside of these to provide details of the latest fully verified `head` _etc_. as they update, if we should re-issue the `head` with `optimistic:false`, or something else.
